Problem Overview

This problem introduces students to comparison statements through the context of claims made about a school fundraising activity. It provides an opportunity to assess students' knowledge and flexibility with additive and multiplicative thinking. In particular, the problem is structured to give insight into whether your students can begin to make multiplicative comparisons (using fractions, ratios, and/or percents) or whether they can only make additive comparisons (using subtraction). You may also have the opportunity to assess students' understanding of equivalent fractions, which is the backbone for developing understanding of ratio. Developing the ability to make multiplicative comparisons is a major goal of this unit.

This problem provides a chance to pre-assess students' sense of multiplicative reasoning. Students are introduced to comparison statements. One statement is additive. For example, the Academy goal is $150 more than Washington's goal. The other statements are multiplicative. For example, for every $60 the Academy students plan to raise, the Central students plan to raise $90.

The ratio is comparison of two quantities that depends on multiplication and division. A difference, by contrast, is a comparison of two quantities that depends on addition and subtraction. The latter does not represent a ratio. Mathematically, students typically come to grade 6 thinking additively, and they tend to compare using differences. This problem involves comparisons of the fundraising goals of different schools. Ratios are informally introduced in "for every" statements, such as "for every $60 Academy raises, Central raises $90."

Management Note: To optimize class time, you may want to cut apart the comparison statements from Learning Aid 1.1: Fundraiser Cards. You can provide sets of the statements in envelopes to pairs of students.

Arc of Learning: Introduction

Standards: See your state alignment chart.

NWDYK

What do you notice about different kinds of comparison statements?

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Build on current use of additive relationships in making comparisons to also include comparison statements that employ multiplicative relationships.

Students may notice

  • some comparisons include one number, others two;
  • comparisons may use fractions, percentage, whole numbers, or "for every" or "for each" language;
  • some comparisons use multiplication, others addition;
  • they compare two or more values for the same thing that may come directly from the context or the values may be scaled; and
  • they help you think about relative sizes—or relationships between quantities

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

Discuss comparison statements like those in the introduction with students. Ask students what kind of comparison statements they have heard, what the context was (sports, social studies, animals, etc.), and what was being compared.

Introduce the context of fundraising. Ask about what experiences students have with fundraisers— either in or out of school. Discuss the idea of a fundraising goal so that everyone is clear on the meaning of this language. (Language) Tell the story of the fundraising campaign at the middle schools in Problem 1.1.

Presenting the Challenge

Distribute Learning Aide 1.1: Fundraiser Cards that have copies of the comparison statements. Make sure students understand that their goal is to evaluate each claim as true or false. They need to be prepared to discuss their reasons. Also, students should analyze the statements for what you know about two of the fundraising goals.

Have students reach each claim quietly and make an initial judgement before talking with a partner to come to a consensus. many teachers assign all statements to each pair of students. An optional launch would be to assign one or two statements to each group of students to analyze. Let the groups know that they will justify their thinking during the class discussion in the summary. Have students begin their work on the comparison statements with a partner and then compare their thinking with another partner group.
